results.title: The Ransom of red chief
results.creator_credit: Marion Rosenberg, Learning Corporation of America and Tony Bill
results.brief_description: Based on the famous O. Henry short story, this humorous film captures the atmosphere of the 1920’s in its settings and spirited music score. Two shabby and inept con men think that kidnapping the banker’s son in a sleepy Alabama town and holding him for two thousand dollars ransom will be easy money. But young Johnny (Red Chief) drives them to distraction with his antics. Cutting short the kidnapping, they rush to the designated spot to pick up the money - only to find the tables again turned.

results.title: The Rakes of Glasgow: a strathspey
results.creator_credit: Stanley Russell, Thames and Clyde Film Company and Scottish Country Dance Society
results.brief_description: Shows the tradiitional Scottish dance, the strathspey danced by three couples to the tunes of “The Rakes of Glasgow” and “Master Francis Sitwell”.

results.title: The Rainmakers
results.creator_credit: S.T. Evans, CSIRO, Division of Radiophysics and M. Graham
results.brief_description: Rainmaking up to recent times has been a mixture of speculation and superstition. From 1946, research and practical experiment have shown that man can induce rain. Shows the “cloud machine” in the CSIRO laboratories, and the first successful, though uneconomical method of seeding cloud with dry ice. The latest method, using silver iodide, is explained, and flights over the Snowy Mountains and Dividing Range, using this chemical, are made with good result.

results.title: The Rainbow serpent
results.brief_description: Set in Dreamtime, this Aboriginal legend about a serpent named Goorialla whose journey across Australia resulted in the creation of the geographical features and the animal and plant life found there today. Based on Dick Roughsey’s award winning series. Narrated by David Gulpilil. No other credits available.

results.title: The Rainbow bear
results.creator_credit: Bill Melendez Productions, American Educational Films and Bill Melendez
results.brief_description: The Rainbow Bear awakes after 400 years of hibernation and takes a walk on the rainbow. Animated story incorporating both verse and prose with elements of impressionistic surrealism. Drawings and written by Robert Merz.

results.title: The Rainbow and the forest
results.brief_description: Of all the butterflies in the British Isles, the “Purple Emperor” is in a class of its own. Apart from the fact that it is so magnificent, most people have never been priviledged to see it in the wild, and collectors regard it as the greatest prize of all. The entire development of this butterfly - the forests it lives in, and its unusual habits were captured on film by a small team who virtually lived with these insects for a year.

results.title: The Rain forest
results.creator_credit: Education Media Australia, David Corke and Bruce Amos
results.brief_description: Filmed in the McPherson Ranges in southern Queensland, capturing the watery atmosphere, eerie sounds, fragile plants and delicate patterns of light which penetrate the dense foliage. The main highlight is a vast camp of flying foxes hanging from the palms, fanning themselves with extended wing membrane.

results.title: The Railwaymen
results.creator_credit: John Richardson, Kestrel Film & Television and Kevin Anderson
results.brief_description: The days of steam which heralded the start of Australia’s inland rail system evoke romantic memories of a bygone era, as well as a recognition of the interdependence between rail and industry success. But what of the people who helped build Australia’s outback railways- the engineers and surveyors whose vision and skill overcame the impossible barriers of desert and mountain range, and the workers who suffered great hardship in building and maintaining them? This documentary uses the words and voices of the men and women that contributed to this history, and those that are continuing to add to it today. Features footage on the following railways: Zig Zag Railway, Blue Mountains; The ABT Railway, Tasmania; The Ghan, Central Australia; Trans-Australia Railway, Nullabor Plain; R-707, Melbourne to Gippsland; and Kuranda Scenic Railway, Queensland.
